item.title: Money is a Gift; Lessons Learned in Business
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1892" align="alignright" width="300" caption="stevendepolo on Flickr"][/caption]

I have recently been burned in two business interactions that left me hurting both financially and personally. Not only did I lose money, I felt taken advantage of and cheapened. I invited my clients to undervalue my hard work by undervaluing it myself. It’s a hard pill to swallow, but I realize it’s all part of the learning process, and the more I delve into business, the more I realize how much good business relies on good character.

item.title: Book Review: Linchpin; and, How to Create a Self-Study Course to Master Anything
item.description: [caption id="attachment_1872" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Vola Vale on Flickr"][/caption] “The best contribution one can make to humanity is to improve oneself.” - Anon I’ve always felt that learning is one of the best ways to improve oneself (I guess you could get philosophical and point out that self-improvement is essentially learning in one form or another). Reading books is one of the best ways to learn, which is why I include a lot of book reviews here.

item.title: The Principles of 'Good' Business
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1840" align="alignright" width="300" caption="digitalmoneyworld on Flickr"][/caption]

“Success means having the courage, the determination, and the will to become the person you believe you were meant to be” -George Sheehan

I recently finished a series three books on how to change the world, how to give as much as possible to your community, and how to help others get the things they need. The first was a book on how to become wealthy, the second was a book about becoming indispensable to your company, and the third was simply a book about selling. Yes, these were business books, but not business books in the way I usually think about the genre.
